title: 109_hr3479
content:
The "Internet Safety and Child Protection Act of 2005" aims to set age verification standards to prevent minors from accessing Internet pornography sites and support law enforcement in combating crimes against children related to the Internet and pornography. The "Child Protection Efforts" section of the "Internet Safety and Child Protection Act of 2005" requires operators of pornographic websites to verify users are 18 or older before displaying any adult content. Financial transactions for these sites must be processed using age-verified credit cards. The Commission is required to ensure regulated pornographic websites use age-screening software and maintain a list of non-compliant sites. Enforcement is carried out by the Federal Trade Commission. SEC. 104. ENFORCEMENT BY THE FEDERAL TRADE COMMISSION. Violations of section 101 are treated as violations of the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding unfair or deceptive acts. The Commission enforces regulations for section 101 similarly to the FTC Act. Violators of these regulations are subject to penalties. SEC. 105. DEFINITIONS. The term "Commission" refers to the Federal Trade Commission. A "regulated pornographic Web site" is defined as a person required to maintain age verification documents under section 2257(a) of title 18, United States Code. TITLE II--FUNDING FOR CHILD PROTECTION Subtitle A--Excise Tax SEC. 201. EXCISE TAX ON INTERNET DISPLAY OR DISTRIBUTION OF PORNOGRAPHY. Chapter 33 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subchapter on Internet Display or Distribution of Pornography. SEC. 4285. Internet display or distribution of pornography. Imposition of a 25% tax on regulated pornographic websites for displaying or distributing pornography online. The tax must be paid by the website operator. Definitions for "pornography" and "regulated pornographic website" are provided. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new subchapter on internet display or distribution of pornography, with an effective date of January 1, 2006. Subtitle B--Child Protection Programs

SEC. 211. TRUST FUND.

Establishes the Internet Safety and Child Protection Trust Fund (referred to as the "trust fund") in the Treasury, funded by taxes collected under section 4285 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amounts in the trust fund are available for programs in section 212, subject to annual appropriations.

SEC. 212. FUNDING FOR CHILD INTERNET SAFETY AND PROTECTION PROGRAMS. The trust fund prioritizes funding for enforcement of the act, development of technology, the Department of Justice cyber tip-line, and the Internet crimes against children task force. The trust fund prioritizes funding for enforcement of the act, development of technology, and supporting Internet Crimes Against Children Task Force centers. Additionally, it establishes a grant process for research and development into new filtering technologies to help parents control children's access to inappropriate content. The Attorney General allocates up to 10% of trust fund revenues for research grants. Educational training funds support child Internet safety and combat sex trafficking. States will receive funding based on their population, with a minimum of $1,000,000 each. 25% of the funding will support child Internet safety training for teachers, and 30% will go towards training law enforcement to combat sex trafficking and crimes against children. After funding priorities for child Internet safety training for teachers and law enforcement, remaining amounts will be allocated to support child Internet safety activities at the federal level. The Federal Agencies involved in supporting child Internet safety activities and combating sex trafficking and crimes against children include the Department of Justice, Department of Commerce, Department of Defense, Department of Education, Department of Health and Human Services, Department of State, Department of Homeland Security, Department of the Treasury, Department of Agriculture, United States Postal Service, Federal Trade Commission, and Federal Communications Commission. The Attorney General will allocate 50 percent of remaining funds through a competitive grant process to support child Internet safety and combat sex trafficking and crimes against children. The Attorney General will allocate funds for international and domestic work under a competitive grant process. The funding limit is $2.5 for domestic work for every $1 allocated for international work. Grant programs will be carried out with prescribed terms and conditions for applications and awards. SEC. 213. DEFICIT REDUCTION. Amounts remaining in the trust fund after funding authorized programs in section 212 will be returned to the Treasury for deficit reduction.
